								[Player review]My review of Streamline based on the experience of a player that does not stream.Streamline is in my opinion an incredibly fun and challenging game because it offers a different experience every time I play. This experience is formed and changed each time by the Players,Viewers and Rules which change every time I play.The movement in Streamline is easy to jump into but requires some practice to get down, don't be afraid to maybe lose a few matches while getting into the game. Once you get the movement in the game down however it opens the gate to play every match in a diffrent style. Be it avoiding the hunter by staying on map wide distance of him/her or challenging the hunter straight on and getting that satisfying "Bear wrestler" accolade at the end of the match by stunning the hunter throughout the game.The look of the game is very cartoony which bases on your prefrences can be either a pro or con.The ability to join and play with a streamer and his/her community can be enjoyable yet for some perhaps a bit scary.For those who enjoy meeting new people I encourage joining on going streams to chat and play together. For those who do not feel the need for community play there has recently been an update which added a "Quick Play" mode. This allowed for players to play without being forced into a new group of people, this mode even eliminated the dependency on streamers to host in order play the game.For streamers who have a smaller group of viewers getting a good feel of the game might feel a little bit challenging at first. However it is still possible to get the most out of Streamline.Streamers are for example able to open their game to both viewers and "Quick play" players, this makes it easier to gain a full party without having a big viewer base. ( The downside is that these players might not join the stream and will thus not join in on the betting and voting/buying rules.)Another way to gain more players is the publicly open discord from the developers "Proletariat". In the discord Streamers are able to advertise to and communitcate with player and other streamers, this often increases the players who are both active on streamote and in-game.A last option would be to join with multiple streamers in one hosted game, through using the (Streamote.tv/Hostofgame/via/secondstreamer). this way each streamer has their own streamote channel and viewers but the betting/voting/buying is shared.Thus yes, it might be hard at first but there are options provided to help you at it.Since there has been quite some changes and additions to the game I will not review this until further in developemnt.I hope this adressed some of the important aspects for players/streamers deciding to play and/or buy streamline.

Product received for free
Early Access Review
Streamline is a fun multiplayer action game filled with parkour, sprinting, gathering points and hitting players.If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.What is happening in the game:You have to run around, being careful not to get hit by the player, currently holding the stop sign. While doing that, you have to gather as many points as possible to climb on the leaderboard. If you get hit by the player with the stop sign, you become the holder of the sign and you are not able to collect points until you manage to hit a player. While the chase is ongoing, random events also occur, an example of those is lava floor.Pros: Graphics | The game looks quite good. I really like that everything is bright and colourful, which is something that I miss in a lot of games. The game itself is quite fast-paced and a different colour scheme would probably confuse players if too many things would be going on at the same time. Animations such as jumping and wall running are also surprisingly well-made. Movement | As mentioned before, this game also includes wall-running, which is very fun to do. Wall-running in weird places usually also enables you to get much more points, which makes it an essential skill to be able to compete for the highest places on the leaderboard. You also have double jumping and trampolines. With those, you can jump really high and have a lot more fun. Character Customization | I was really surprised by the amount of character customization this game is offering. You can change almost everything: your shirt, your pants, your shoes, your face, your skin and so on. Most of the available items also have a number of different colours to choose from, which lets you create the perfect colour combination for you. Twitch Integration | Although integrating Twitch so deeply into the game also has a big downside which I will mention later in this review, I have to say that it also brings a lot of fun into this game. As one viewer sets up his stream, other players can join his party. Viewers of that person's stream can then bet on any player in the party they want using their in-game coins. They can also select an event, which will then occur in the game and influence all players. (Random) Events | As written above, viewers of one's stream can pick an event that will influence the game. If there aren't viewers or none of them choose to pick an event, an event is selected randomly every once in a while. Those events can really make the game much better. Let me list some of those events: Lava Floor (you must not touch the ground or your die), No Touching (if you touch another player, you die), Concrete Feet (you can't double jump), Continuous Jumping (you can't stop jumping) and a few more. I probably got a few names wrong, I apologise for that. Maps | There are currently 6 maps in Streamline, all of them are quite good. Some of them have more trampolines than others, some have much better wall-climbing. If you get to choose the map, there is certainly a map which is right for you. Pack Drops | After most matches, you will get a pack of items shaped like one of those bags you go to fitness with. The better you perform, the better are the chances of getting a pack of higher value. Each pack contains one or two things. You can either get a new item (most commonly a piece of clothing, a hairstyle or a pair of shoes) or, if you get two items, the second one can be a new colour for one of the items you already have. I really like that you get those packs so often because there are quite a lot of things to be unlocked. Achievements | There are 49 achievements in this game and they contribute a lot to the overall quality of this game. They are really fun to achieve as they actually reward you for something special you do, not for grinding something for a long time.Cons: Twitch Requirement | As much as Twitter integration can be fun, I find it weird that you can only play the game after logging in with Twitch and setting up some things first. I don't really have a desire to stream my gameplay and I'm also not really keen on being on someone else's stream. Developers are supposedly thinking of getting rid of this requirement, but as of now, it still exists in the game. Hit Detection | Sometimes, you get hit by players that are not really that close, but you still get hit. If you figure how to use this, it's very easy to kill other players, which is (in my opinion) giving an unfair advantage to some players. Connectivity Problems | When I try to start playing, I am sometimes not able to do so because of some server communication problems. The issue usually goes away in a few minutes and it's not really that often, but it's still worth mentioning. Resolution Issues | When I play in fullscreen mode, I can't see all of the menus properly. When I wanted to check the commands in the options menu, I had to switch to windowed mode, or some of the menu would be cut off for some reason. Pricing | Honestly, I'm not sure if $20 is the right price tag for this game. Sure, it has a lot of content and it's pretty fun, but for $20 you can get some much better games-The final verdict:The game is certainly very fun. Although it was lacking players a month ago, the influx of new players certainly gave this game a huge boost and now it's not ever a problem to find somebody to play with. The game looks awesome and plays awesome, which outweighs most of the negative things in this game.If you're looking for some fun multiplayer action, this is certainly the way to go. Although the price is a bit high, there's no reason not to get this for yourself when it's on discount.With love,BirdCuteNote that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

								Opinion:**I love this game- when I found out about it this summer I was blown away that more people weren’t paying attention to it.  As a streamer on Twitch I am always looking for games that get the chat involved- many times the game I am playing has zero integration and occasionally it is nice to provide an experience that is all-inclusive for the viewers.  Here's the basic gameplay description:There is one game mode currently: Elimination which pits the “hunter” against the “runners” to gather the most points before getting eliminated! The parkour movement allows everyone to get around the level with ease: double jump, sprint, power slide, and dodge left/right. The hunter is the only one with a melee weapon and their goal is eliminate the runners- pretty simple! The hunter also recharges stamina over time where the runners are vulnerable with limited stamina (runners pick up lightning bolts to refill it). The hunter is normally the host of the game who is streaming on Twitch but you can also choose another person to be hunter or a random choice.The runners can punch the hunter / other runners if they have good timing and use the parkour movement to avoid them.  If you get eliminate you come back as a ghost to “haunt/grief” other runners. Press G to taunt their failures (or pay your respects).It’s a tug of war to get the most points with unpredictable rulesets that are voted on in the chat through the proprietary streamote.tv site where you (using a virtual points system) can bet on who wins, buy rules from the rules store, vote on rulesets during the game, and play Bingo!  Chaotic, action packed with an excellent soundtrack that will leave your head bobbing involuntarily. (available on Spotify, Google Play etc.)How to get started:Once you launch the game you will connect your Twitch account which is super easy to do- then your ingame name will match your Twitch name.Click on inventory* to customize your character- before you “get good” you gotta look good. Just sayin’!!The options menu has the ability to view / rebind controls (I play with inverted mouse).If you are a solo player you can just hit quick play* and get into the action- you will be assigned to a random party.  Once you find a game you can go to the host’s streamote.tv site- for instance if Kappa was playing Streamline theirs would be streamote.tv/Kappa However, where this game shines is the Twitch integration for streamers- using the streamote.tv site that gives everyone something to do- the host (streamer) chooses who is allowed to join the party- open for anyone to join including those who use the “quick play*” feature, invite only to choose specific people, and subscribers only for a quick and easy Sub Sunday event!  The party system even detects who owns the game for ease of use when inviting players.  One of my favorite additions recently was the quick play* feature which allows new players who don’t understand how the streamote.tv site works yet a way to get into a game and meet other players.  And this is a game that can get quite competitive- I was recently at TwitchCon and saw in person how the skill ceiling for Streamline is something that no one really expected.  I got a chance to talk to the best players in the game right now and they are all very friendly but once the game starts so does the competition.  Conclusion / tl;dr:A fast paced, smooth parkour Pacman where one hunter aims to eliminate the runners asap!  A great game for streamers to involve everyone in the chat and get things hype!  The current game mode is limited and there is a high ceiling for potential other game modes.  Team Elimination will be all I play once that mode is finalized. Currently there are 5 maps and many different customization options including exclusive Steam items or Twitch Prime items if you end up owning that version too (free on Twitch Prime through October).  As a streamer this is a must play- if you are the competitive type you can try to take the crown from the best players currently.  Best and only game of its type out there. Worth.*Inventory and Quick Play, other features are this way as of the current version and may be subject to change.**Objective opinion, not compensated for this review. 								After sitting down with Streamline for just a few hours, I know this is definitely a game to watch. It's still in early access, with a few rough edges, but Proletariat looks to be pouring additional support into the game, so I'm guessing we'll see a lot of improvement. In the meantime, it's a pretty great game for some quick multiplayer sessions.First off, player movement is a blast. While it's super easy to get the hang of wall-running, double-jumping, and boosting around a level, the best players I faced were able to pull off some amazing moves. (Very much in the "how the heck did they do that" vein.)Rounds are also quick, and eliminated players don't have to just sit and watch the remaining runners play. They can interfere as "ghosts," stunning other players and chasing after "haunt" targets for extra points in the round. (Yes, you can keep scoring points when you're dead.) Some of the game mods play around with ghosts as well, like giving them the ability to eliminate other players or even come back to life for a short time.I did have a few issues with the game: between each game you have to wait a few minutes while stream spectators place bets on the players and use their stream currency to purchase what game mods will appear in each round. If you're not engaging with the stream, (which as far as I can tell requires running Streamote in the background,) this part of the game can drag on. More integration of the stream tools and chat with the game itself is something I'd look forward to in the future.The game mod system in general also adds some great variety to each round, but otherwise it's mainly there to give spectators a way to interact with the game, since players don't interact with it much themselves.If you're a streamer, this game is a must, even in Early Access, but even if you don't stream, there's still something here for you. I imagine it's especially good for LAN parties or played wherever you and your friends can smacktalk each other.

								Streamline looks more complicated in gameplay videos than it actually is. Within a few rounds you can get a good grip of the game. The game can include up to 16 players. 15 Runners plus a Hunter. The Hunter has the ability to kill the Runners in one hit. The runners compete for points by collecting orbs of differing values while using a dash meter. The dash meter is filled by pickups and you gain more points if you collect orbs while dashing. The movement in the game is context sensitive, as you can wall-run and do similar acrobatic feats while holding a button. If you are killed, you become a ghost. A ghost can no longer collect orbs, but can gain an increasing amount of points by punching a randomly assigned, still-alive runner. The game is played in 3 rounds that last a few minutes and the point total is cumulative, so if you die early in the first round, you can try to make up for it in the second round (and perhaps sabotage the runners who have amassed more points than you). If you are still alive at the end of a round, ghosts disappear and a sudden death commences, where you are finally able to kill the hunter by landing a hit on him, you just have to survive long enough and land a hit. The Hunter is scored via a letter grade (F- to A+ it seems), while the runner with the most points wins.There is intergration with twitch, as you can host or join lobbies by linking your twitch account in-game and then using the developer's twitch player at https://streamote.tv/. You do not have to install anything, as some people seem to be confused on how this works. The end result is that you are able to find lobbies via this website, join a party, and play with a streamer (or if you are a streamer yourself, host). Viewers are able to view the stream of the game and use a point system to influence the game through different global buffs/debuffs that they choose when to activate. They can also bet on who they think will win and rack up more points via bingo in the lobby.To put it simply it's a competitive score-based platformer with asymetrical gameplay (Hunter, Runner & Ghost). It also involves optional stream integration, so that viewers may influence the gameplay. It's still early-access at this point, but feels solid and I have enjoyed the quirky experience so far. Recommended.

From making your character run around in their underpants to having them wear antlers, a gas mask or a hoodie. You can even change your race and gender at any time. 			My review of "Streamline", multiplayer free-for-all game about free-running with Twitch integration developed and published by Proletariat Inc. Copy supplied by developer.		

Game: StreamlineGenre: Free-for-All MultiplayerDeveloper: Proletariat Inc.Publisher: Proletariat Inc.Copy supplied by developerStreamline is a multiplayer free-for-all game about free-running with Twitch integration developed and published by Proletariat Inc.GRAPHICSDeveloped with Unreal Engine 4, the game's cell-shaded graphics and cartoonish look are polished and pretty. While nothing mind-blowing, each level looks and feels different, and there are enough small buildings to climb and crates to vault without being too big or overcrowded.GAMEPLAYThe game is a 16 player free-for-all version of Tag. One player is the Hunter, and he has to hit another player to make him become the Hunter, while everyone else is a Runner, and they have to collect as many points as possible.The free-running feels smooth but never too fast for its own good. The big gimmick of the game is that it is integrated with Twitch, and viewers can interact directly by adding powerups and variables: turn the floor to lava, force all players to jump or only move sideways, remove all points from the map, etc. They are fun and they do make each game feel different from the others.The only issue I have is that it lacks variety at its core: there are no other game modes right now, and there is a lack of players, so good luck in finding a full server.CHALLENGEThe game isn't particularly hard, and you get the grasp of the controls and parkour very fast. Runners can punch each other to steal points and let the Hunter get to them first, but it still isn't enough to change the tides of your situation. It is really hard for you to succesfully recover from a last position after the first round, but thankfully the game is pretty fast and you can level up pretty easily nontheles, making the experience not frustrating.SOUNDThe soundtrack by Matthew Harwood and Breakmaster Cylinder is solid and fun, bringing a lot of energy to the game. The sound effects are fun, with a couple of noises that tend to get annoying in the long run.REPLAYABILITYThe Twitch integration and its Early Access status make this a solid game to play multiple times in the future. Hopefully the player base will increase.Overall, this is a solid multiplayer game with a nice gimmick and solid controls. Recommended!Story: n/a

								De: www.crgamershub.clubLa oferta que encontramos en Streamline es sencilla, donde eres un Cazador o Corredor, si fuiste seleccionado para comenzar la partida como Cazador te ves en la necesidad de buscar a los demás jugadores para golpearlos y poder convertirte en Corredor, si te toca ser Corredor tu objetivo es conseguir puntos. El juego es desarrollado por el equipo independiente Proletariat Inc.Quizás la característica principal del juego sea el enfoque que tiene hacia la plataforma Twitch, que por si no lo conoces, es un servicio gratis para realizar o mirar streams de juegos de video, etc. El juego esta diseñado y creado pensando en ofrecer streams calidad. Stramline permite a los jugadores que utilizan Twitch para transmitir sus partidas interactuar con sus espectadores; los que estén viendo la partida pueden participar directamente en las rondas, apostando por sus jugadores favoritos, cambiando las reglas de las rondas en tiempo real y competir en mini-juegos.Lo mencionado en el párrafo anterior es posible gracias al Streamote.tv, un sitio web creado por los mismos chicos de Proletaria, una herramienta que permite a los streamers y espectadores interactuar entre ellos mientras juegan Streamline sin tener que hacer un desmadre en el chat de Twitch.El título se juega en linea, en partidas de hasta 16 jugadores, donde ya sea como Cazador o Corredor nos vemos enfrascados en partidas donde las reglas del juego cambian a según las elecciones de los espectadores de la partida, con game changers chistosos, como por ejemplo: uno de los cambios en tiempo real nos limita a solo poder caminar como un cangrejo, de medio lado (y haciendo pantomima de cangrejo), otras nos ponen a brincar durante un minutos (sin que lo queramos), otras ralentizan el tiempo y todo va en cámara lenta. También existen cambios en el mapa, como que empieza a llenarse de lava en el suelo afectando los jugadores, o el mapa se empieza a hacer más pequeño poco a poco. Acá pueden ver un video del juego que subimos a nuestra pagina de Facebook.Otra característica es la posibilidad de poder cambiar la ropa y accesorios de tu personaje, con cientos de combinaciones posibles dándole un toque mas personal, con distintas ropas y muchos colores divertidos.Streamline es un juego que podría ser más divertido, pero se queda un poco corto. El problema no es que sea poco divertido, el asunto es que el título es un poco lento, la jugabilidad se siente lenta, y se atenúa aun más cuando todo en el titulo se centra en correr. Para mi gusto los jugadores tienen poca velocidad, y eso le resta emoción. Los saltos, piruetas y plataformeo serían más emocionantes si el desarrollador le añadiera un poco más de velocidad a los personajes, convirtiendo la experiencia en algo más vertiginoso y dinámico.Los gráficos de Stramline son regulares, con un aire a Team Fortress y Battleborn, no son ni malos ni buenos. El audio es sumamente molesto para mi gusto, pero no es peor que el “reggaeton” de la vecina al frente de mi casa, así pues, es recomendable bajarle el sonido al audio y poner tu propia música para evitar algún cáncer en el tímpano.En corto, Streamline no lo hace mal, las cosas que merman la experiencia son fácilmente corregibles y con el tiempo podría ser un juego regular-bueno, vacilón para jugar con los amigos. Un juego que cuesta originalmente $20, lo cual es caro para la experiencia que ofrece, asi que mejor agarrarlo mientras se pueda.

								For a full picture of what this game is like, there are plenty of reviews one can read, or even watch videos from your favorite streamer or ‘tuber and educate themselves about the game and all the small details it entails, I'm not here to write a full review, but to simply make a small first impression comment, which is the following;Streamline is the red-headed step child of what you would get if Mirror's Edge and Pixar decided to make the first community driven Parkour game that focuses on streamlined (har-har) map activities, rather then being open world, via the gratifying fast paced game-play and loot system akin that of Overwatch.However, the praises stop there.The game suffers from a chicken or egg situation, I cannot attest if it's because the community (at least here on Steam) is passing barely the 130 people mark on a day to day basis, or because the servers refuse to put people together, but the community is more scarce then even Dark Souls 1 ever was during past summer (and that's saying something considering networking was broken by BamCo in DS1 during 2016).Fan's don't want to admit this, but it's true, the matchmaking is a nightmare to say the least.On several occasions, in Streamline, I idled for not 5 or 10, but almost 50 minutes flat waiting for a match to start, and this is during mid-day in NA region, where apparently most users are online. I can only imagine what a pain it must be during the ‘off-hours’ (you know, when people are off work and actually can play games) when around those times, the population can drop as low as below 50.Forget about playing late at night, because unless you enter the Twilight Zone for EU and Asian time zone, and meet your occasional late time players, there literally won't be anyone playing.Say what you want, but if an old 5 year old ‘dead’ game which only has the most basic of networking (Dark Souls) still is able to have people playing together in less then 5 minutes, I think it’s fair to say Streamline has some issues.Even though in theory that shouldn’t be an issue, because a match is a match and a match can allocate up to 15 people, so at any given time, with about 150 people, I should be easily finding 10 matches ongoing, I still find myself barely scrapping by in 4 people matches.You best bet is to idle in Streamote and wait for someone to Stream the game then and join their public party. This is the best bet at finding constant matches, or wait for the specific week-days in which the Dev's themselves Stream the game, which seems to be always bursting with people strangely enough.Maybe Streamline will bounce (pun intended) around and become essentially a more casual version of Overwatch without guns, or maybe, some smarmy British accented ‘tuber will make a video and inject some new blood in the game, or maybe all those ♥♥♥♥♥ who were idling in the game for 10 cents cards will finally decide to play games instead of working for chicken feed.

								Streamline has nailed the party game format, but the most I can say is I'm glad I got it for free - It's mildly entertaining for about 30 minute sessions, but the problem with games based around Twitch interaction is that they're entirely throwaway.It's an incredbly simplistic game that already feels dated due to some of the terms in game (Ripperoni/Crabcore etc.) that are meant to be hilarious, but aren't funny the first time (Nor anytime after that) and ultimately makes the game feel like it should be played soley by the very audience it's going for; screaming Twitch users and their teenage fans that are entertained by random gameplay and XD humour. It's clear from the beginning that there's very little depth, in part due to the random nature of the modifiers that thrown in, which frustrate more than they entertain (Which I'm sure is great for the twitch audience, but not much fun for the player). The parkour mechanics are OK at best - the levels work relatively well around them but if I don't feel certain that I'm going to wall-run everytime I attempt to wall-run then you have ultimately failed at creating a good parkour game, nevermind any additional mechanics that improve a parkour game even further. The levels are a decent size but the way they're slowly closed off is frustrating and should probably only start in the sudden death section. The aforementioned section itself is quite annoying too, as the attack with the stop sign seems to hit enemies after the swing animation is finished but prior to the sign being placed on the characters back again, resulting in unsatisfying kills and frustrating deaths (I can't say that for certain, nor do I intend to go back and test if that is the case). I can't see the multiplayer community sticking around for long either (Especially with no in-game chat function or mode to just run around the maps with others). To sum up, it's not worth £15; maybe a fiver at most. If you manage to see this while the game is free for the day give it a download and see what you think, you might enjoy it more than I do. Maybe I'm reading too much into a game where you're supposed to just turn your brain off and have fun, but that just brings me back to my main point; it's a throwaway game. As my main interest in it was the parkour system which isn't particularly good, I won't be playing much more of it and I can't see many others playing it either.

								i really wanted to enjoy this game. but heres my few problems with it. for a game that kinda bills itself as speedy in general, the actual movement in game is pretty slow. consider it like Jet Grind Radio, instead of Jet Set Radio Future. same attitude, but much slower in all aspects. if they made the boost speed standard speed, and made boost faster, it might be more fun.but then theres the modifiers. "cement shoes", "slow thuggin". these pop up very rapidly, often just as the last one is ending. i had a match where the entire game was in slow motion because we got slow thugging over and over. these *might* make the game more fun, if they didn't happen so often. as it is, they kill the pacing. lastly, theres the "closed area" rule. where less than a minute into a game, half of the level gets closed off and kills you if you go in. this might be better as a more gradual effect, but no, its a big nope stamp coming all at once. on one level, in the last 3 minutes of a match, everywhere was closed off except for a narrow platform suspended between two buildings. locking off areas of a free running game sorta seems like a mis-step to me.in any case, this game has a serious problem of too many mechanics. cut out any two, and the game might be a lot more enjoyable. maybe future patches will help. as it stands, i cannot reccomend it.

								At this stage of the game, I'm going to say that it isn't satisfying to play. When you start up the game you are forced to use a twitch account which is unreasonable as you should be given the option to create an 'in-game' account. Also, when logging into twitch, you find the browser they set up is very slow and unresponsive.To create your own game you have to start streaming on twitch which for some can cause slow gameplay due to the strain on their internet. If you join someone else's game you find that their are 0 people in any lobby, other than you, which makes the game unplayable as you can't play with other players.The graphic quality is quite unusual as 'Low' and 'Medium' are quite unpleasent to look at and 'Ultra' causes PC's to start losing frame rate. 'High' quality is quite unusual to look at as there always seems to be a slight blur which can make it hard to focus sometimes.However, the game does seem to be quite fun with an emphasis on fast-pace gameplay with a  very simplistic look and  an exciting theme. Also, the Valve-themed cosmetics does bring in all the 'fan-boys and girls' to play which can bring in a larger audience to meet and play with.I can see the game improving in the future to make it actually be playable and functionable but at this current time; I would'nt reccomend this game untill a future update.

								Streamline is a game that's nailed the party game format, but the most I can say is I'm glad I got it for free - It's mildly entertaining for about 30 minute sessions, but the problem with games based around Twitch interaction is that they're entirely throwaway.It's an incredbly simplistic game that already feels dated due to some of the terms in game (Ripperoni/Crabcore etc.) that are meant to be hilarious, but aren't funny the first time (Nor anytime after that) and ultimately makes the game feel like it should be played soley by the very audience it's going for; screaming Twitch users and their teenage fans that are entertained by random gameplay and XD humour. It's clear from the beginning that there's very little depth, in part due to the random nature of the modifiers that thrown in, which frustrate more than they entertain (Which I'm sure is great for the twitch audience, but not much fun for the player). The parkour mechanics are OK at best - the levels work relatively well around them but if I don't feel certain that I'm going to wall-run everytime I attempt to wall-run then you have ultimately failed at creating a good parkour game. The levels are a decent size but the way they're slowly closed off is frustrating and should probably only start in the sudden death section. The aforementioned section itself is quite annoying too, as the attack with the stop sign seems to hit enemies after the swing animation is finished prior to the sign being placed on the characters back again, resulting in unsatisfying kills and frustrating deaths (I can't say that for certain, nor do I intend to go back and test if that is the case). I can't see the multiplayer community sticking around for long either (Especially with no in-game chat function or mode to just run around the maps with others). To sum up, it's not worth £15; maybe a fiver at most. If you manage to see this while the game is free for the day give it a download and see what you think, you might enjoy it more than I do. Maybe I'm reading too much into a game where you're supposed to just turn your brain off and have fun, but that just brings me back to my main point; it's a throwaway game. As my main interest in it was the parkour system which isn't particularly good, I won't be playing much more of it and I can't see many others playing it either.

								   "Get the ball into the goal" is too simple a premise for you to call it an orginal game. There's plenty of games that do that, but there are usually complexities that make the game interesting and fun otherwise; adding new elements, tight mechanics, or complex rules. This game fails in all of those regards. It lacks anything that makes a game interesting.    It's art style is colorful in a way that seems almost sterile, like a test pattern. None of the pick-ups seem to do anything, they have numbers on them so I assume they're money, but what for? Your characters appearance? There aren't any skill trees or anything, so I really can't see what collecting these little tokens is even good for.    The animations are clunky and the controls seem unresponsive because of it, making you feel like you need to wait for an animation to be done to give your character a command. The goal of the game seems to be just to run around. I'm being literal there, and not overly reductive; there doesn't seem to be any incentive to get the ball into the goal so most players just seem to run around and parkour the tiny levels.   I want to separate this paragraph, and note that my feelings on the SJW-ness of this game did not influence my feelings on the quality of the game itself too greatly. It's a crappy game despite that. That said, the world built in this game (what little world was built) is so overtly preachy in it's left-ness that it almost seems like the only reason the developers made it in the first place.    The blurb that the creators came up with on the Steam page reads like an seventh grade girl trying to make up a sport that will still let her eat cake and daydream about horses. That's a bit of a stretch maybe, but it just reeks of  immature "no Boys allowed" type garbage.    Then there's the fact that the character that everyone starts out with is a black woman, in a sassy pose, and a wide smirk on her face. The only thing that doesn't bother me is the fact that it's a black woman. What does bother me is the smirk and defiant pose. It's like the developers are saying "Yeah, this black woman is the default and there's nothing you can do about it, you racist!" when there wasn't anyone saying otherwise in the first place. To me, staunch defiance in the face of zero opposition is just as cowardly as fleeing or shrinking from opposition.   Then instead of "gender" there's just a "body type" option, which changes you from looking feminine to looking masculine. Again, nothing inherently wrong with a gender neutral game, but making it seem like you've done everyone a favor is obnoxious.    My main problem with all stuff like this is how cheap it all is when you look at it as a whole. When I was a kid my parents were SUPER CHRISTIAN, and they would only buy Christian music and watch Christian movies and buy Christian postage stamps or whatever. At around the age of eleven or so I began to notice that if you didn't look so hard at the message the thing was trying to shove down your throat, you were left with a production so sub-par that really kind of insulted the audience with how bad it was. Stuff that caters to SJWs is the same thing to me. It's preachy and annoying, and when you look more closely you realize that it's cheap and crappy too.

								I got this game back when it was in closed alpha and played it a bit, then went and forgot about it. I recently just picked it up again, and it's a blast. Basically, depending on the mode, it can be described like this: Multiplayer Mirror's edge where you have to avoid one guy who wants to murder you, Multiplayer Mirror's edge where you're playing basketball/soccer, or multiplayer Mirror's edge while you're playing tag.Now it's not perfect. The movement needs tuning since it feels sloppy in a lot of cases, and takes a while getting used to. Additionally the game doesn't really take balance into account. This isn't a problem in the free for all modes, but in the "bitball" mode (the one that's like soccer/basketball), there are two teams and it's up to the host to balance it manually. This can lead to wildly unbalanced bitball games.The last downside to the game is it currently has a very low playerbase. However, the developers run streams of the game several days a week, with a bunch of people joining in. I recommend people join the discord and watch for alerts on the stream announcement channel.Now the last question, is it worth $20? Well, probably not. Don't get me wrong, it's an amazing game, but the amount of variety it has right now isn't worth it. However if the devs succeed in fulfilling their promises of new modes, it will likely be worth $20 easily. From what I've seen so far, the devs look like they'll be able to do that, but you'll have to judge for yourself whether it's worth the risk.
